thread.title: Jaden Stroobant pleads guilty to murder of West Auckland woman Cun Xiu Tian
thread.title_full: Jaden Stroobant pleads guilty to murder of West Auckland woman Cun Xiu Tian

author: Kelly Dennett
title: Jaden Stroobant pleads guilty to murder of West Auckland woman Cun Xiu Tian
text:
Jaden Stroobant at the High Court at Auckland, where he plead guilty to murder. Relevant offers National News NZ dual nationals exempt from Trump's US Muslim travel ban Man killed in nose-to-tail crash south of Christchurch Jaden Stroobant pleads guilty to murder of West Auckland woman Cun Xiu Tian Weather stymies rescue of Welsh climber on Mt Cook Stolen car stripped of parts and set on fire in Levin Truck fire brings traffic to standstill on State Highway One near Warkworth "Striking" new images show impact of Kaikoura earthquake on the sea floor Bill English legally can't live in Premier House Jogger, 70, in critical condition after being hit by car Blood scare sparks nationwide dental clinic checks 
A man set to stand trial for the murder of an elderly Te Atatu woman has pleaded guilty at the last minute. 
Jaden Lee Stroobant, 20, had denied one charge of murder and two charges of sexual violation of 69-year-old Cun Xiu Tian. 
He was due to stand trial at the High Court at Auckland on Wednesday. 
Instead, he entered guilty pleas at a formal arraignment and convictions were entered. 
Justice Graham Lang gave him a first strike warning under the Three Strikes Act. 
A sentencing date was set for March 13. 
Prosecutor Jo Murdoch said the Crown would be seeking a sentence of preventive detention- an indeterminate sentence length imposed on serious offenders to protect the public. 
Suppression orders currently prevent publication of details of Stroobant's sexual offending against Tian, and his defence lawyer Emma Priest argued the orders should continue. 
Justice Lang agreed to keep them in place until a substantive hearing on the matter. 
Priest argued that publication of the specific details of the sexual violation charges would jeopardise Stroobant's safety in prison. 
She told Justice Lang that on Tuesday Stroobant had voluntarily segregated himself from other inmates. 
Tian's body was found at the Te Atatu Peninsula home she shared with her family on January 15, 2016. 
She was badly beaten in what police described at the time as a prolonged attack. 
A trial was meant to go ahead in November last year but was adjourned.
